LeaseAgreement.title: LeaseAgreement
LeaseAgreement.description: Represents a lease agreement between a landlord and a tenant.

id.description: Unique identifier for the lease agreement.

tenantContact.description: Contact information of the tenant (e.g., phone number, email).

propertyUnit.description: The unit or suite number of the property.

leaseStartDate.description: The date the lease agreement starts.

leaseEndDate.description: The date the lease agreement ends.

monthlyRent.description: The amount of rent due each month.

Payment.title: Payment
Payment.description: Represents a payment made by a tenant.

paymentDate.description: The date the payment was made.

definition.description: Stores lease agreements owned by a specific user. Authorization is based on path-based ownership. Includes denormalized 'userId' for authorization independence.

params.name: userId
params.description: The ID of the user (landlord) who owns the lease agreement.

params.name: leaseAgreementId
params.description: The ID of the lease agreement.

definition.description: Stores payments related to a specific lease agreement. Authorization is inherited from the lease agreement's ownership. Includes denormalized 'userId' and 'leaseAgreementId' for authorization independence.

params.name: userId
params.description: The ID of the user (landlord) who owns the lease agreement.

params.name: leaseAgreementId
params.description: The ID of the lease agreement.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to manage lease agreements and payments efficiently. Each lease agreement is stored under a specific landlord's user ID, providing clear ownership and access control. Payments are then stored as subcollections within each lease agreement, enabling easy retrieval of payment history for a specific lease. This design emphasizes path-based ownership, which simplifies security rules and provides clear data isolation. To achieve Authorization Independence, no denormalization is needed as access control relies solely on path-based ownership, with each landlord having full access to data stored under their respective user ID.

This structure is QAP-compliant because:

1.  **Segregation:** Lease agreements and payments are stored separately, which clarifies access needs and simplifies rules.
2.  **Path-Based Ownership:** Each landlord's data is isolated under their `userId`, preventing unauthorized access to other landlords' information.
3.  **Hierarchical paths for User-Owned Data**: It supports the `User 1:N Entity` relationship using path-based ownership.
